text: just because the person can't walk or
just because the person has you know no
legs or maybe one arm or whatever the
case may be that they're still fully
functioning happy members of society and
they deserve to be treated just like you
would treat a person with working arms
working legs whatever
my name is Joshua George I'm 24 years
old and this summer I'll be representing
the u.s. at the Beijing Paralympic Games
I absolutely love with racing I
love everything that goes along with it
I've developed a tight network of
friends who also raise from all over the
world I love the feeling of the actual
competition of beforehand of after the
race for my class I am the top-ranked
racer in the world for the 100 200 400
and 800 meter races on the track
well when I was when I was four years
old my parents ed had laid me down in my
bedroom I supposed to be taking a nap
and like like most four year olds I
wasn't really doing what I was supposed
to be doing and so I climbed up on the
windowsill and started shuffling across
to get the toy or whatever I wanted from
the shelf and when I was halfway across
the the windowsill I felt kind of tired
and I leaned backwards so screen popped
out and I fell out with it fell 12
stories to the ground so I broke both my
femurs I dislocated my hips and I
bruised my spinal cord when I left the
hospital I was in a full-body cast from
my shoulders to my feet and I had pins
keeping my hips keeping my femurs into
the into the socket so the first thing
you have to do after the accident is
reteach yourself how to live without the
use of your lower body I had to learn
how to use a wheelchair I had to learn
how to use braces and crutches so I
guess or to walk around in braces and
leg braces you know I always enjoyed
pushing my my chair really fast and when
I was in rehab in Delaware I would
always get in trouble from the nurses
for racing around the halls as fast as I
could
in the in the early 90s I had the
opportunity to run an actual race you
know with the starting line and a finish
line but I did it in my in my everyday
chair and I ran it and I won the race
and I loved it I had a I had a blast
when I when I look at myself i I don't
really see that I'm disabled or
handicapped part of that probably is the
fact that I hate the word disabled it
has such a negative connotation to it
and even if you break it down in its
parts it doesn't really mean anything
positive it means that you're not able
to do something and the fact that I'm
not able to walk isn't really a negative
so I mean I look at myself I'm a guy in
a wheelchair I push around instead of
walking around my life is really no
different than anybody else's on a
day-to-day basis I'm a completely
independent individual I have my own car
I you know if I need to drive somewhere
I could drive somewhere on my own I just
toss my chair either in the backseat or
the passenger seat of the car and I have
a used hand controls just a handheld
version of the pedals basically and
drive myself around okay to rely on
somebody else to drive me around I've
been lost I go to the store and get
whatever I want I can walk around town I
mean I'm go out to eat go out hang out
with friends go to concerts whatever it
may be my diet as it is I don't even
know if you could call it a diet as I
basically am on the Seif seafood diet
and I see it I eat it
breakfast of champions right now where
I'm at in life I am my job is basically
to race to train and to race
the the most important person in in my
my racing life right now is definitely
my coach Adam lightning he he trains
with me every day
and he's the one that devises the
workout plan and keeps me focused and go
to Switzerland and then we'll train to
Switzerland for for what's coming up and
for the ultimate goal of this year which
would be Beijing this is probably the
busiest time of the year for me
athletically I am travelling just about
every weekend I've been I've been gone
more than I've been home since January
when I am home I just try to relax I
enjoy having a comfortable couch I enjoy
my own bed I really only have time to to
do some laundry to lay around watch a
movie or two and then I'm off again
basically the only thing that I will
never be able to do is be a professional
soccer player I mean that's sorta that's
rule that was ruled out a while ago I
don't I don't feel that there is
anything that I'd ever have to do that I
that I won't be able to do because I'm
confined to a wheelchair
